Award.AwardTitle: Promoting a Diverse Computing Workforce: Using National Survey Data to Understand Persistence Across Undergraduate Student Groups

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The need for increased participation of individuals from underrepresented groups in computer science is well documented. This project makes use of a large, diverse data set to better understand the issues of identify and self-efficacy that contribute to persistence in underrepresented groups in computer science. The project capitalizes on an existing NSF-funded infrastructure that annually surveys a national sample of students enrolled in a diverse array of computing programs. Specifically, this project leverages the Computing Research Association's (CRA) Center for Evaluating the Research Pipeline (CERP), which collects large scale, cross sectional survey data concerning the experiences of students pursuing computing career tracks from a variety of institution types and from a wide array of demographic groups. By evaluating self-efficacy and identity across a large and broad data set from a diverse population of students and institutions, a much better picture of factors influencing student persistence is being generated.

The proposed research is interested in predicting persistence among a variety of student groups in computing. The hypotheses that will guide this study are: (1) Self-efficacy, occupational values, and social identity threat predict engagement and persistence in computing, (2) Group differences in perceived threat will predict group differences in self-efficacy and, subsequently, group disparities in engagement and persistence, and (3) Social support will attenuate the negative effects of self-efficacy and social identity threat on engagement and prediction. Two surveys will be administered over the course of the project to assess the proposed theoretical model of student persistence. The first survey will be administered to a national sample of undergraduate and graduate computing students that will measure engagement and intentions to persist in computing and their hypothesized predictors. The second survey will measure engagement and intentions to persist again (i.e., changes over time), as well as actual persistence. A series of analyses will examine each of the hypotheses implicated by the theorized model. A structural equation modeling will be used to assess overall model fit and examine relations among variables.

This research informs the development of best practices and new interventions that positively impact retention of a wide variety of underrepresented populations in computer science nationwide. This project combines a strong theoretical background and unique social science perspective with an unmatched data collection infrastructure provided by CERP. Project evaluation is conducted by an advisory board throughout all phases of the project. The objectives that will be measured are the scope of the dissemination of the data produced and the number of interventions developed by educators and administrators who use the data. Consistent contact with an advisory board results in the collection of high caliber data from a diverse population of students and the dissemination of results in a way that is a accessible and useful to a general audience with interest in STEM education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Focusing on postsecondary students' experiences in the field of computing (e.g., computer science, computer engineering, information sciences, and any other technological-driven field), this project was developed to (a) collect data systematically and longitudinally (i.e., over time), (b) conduct social scientific research, with a particular focus on student groups who have identities considered underrepresented in computing, and (c) disseminate both data and research findings to communities of interest. Ultimately, the project findings were intended to contribute to efforts to broaden participation in computing and diversify the US technological workforce.

Throughout this project, the team (i.e., Center for Evaluating the Research Pipeline (CERP)) collected national survey data that served as a unique contribution to the field of computing. Drawing upon the Computing Research Association's (CRA) vast network of members and affiliates, and the CRA's strong reputation, the project team collected over 75,000 responses from undergraduate and graduate students in computing and technology fields, 32,000 of whom participated in the projects' longitudinal data collection efforts.

In order to understand the factors that impact students' persistence in the computing field, this project examined social scientific outcomes such as sense of belonging, self-confidence, social and professional support structures, research experiences, and participation in professional events such as conferences--all factors that have been shown to be related to student retention in academic settings. This project examined students' experiences by a number of demographic characteristics including race/ethnicity, gender, disability status, first generation college student status, sexual orientation, and combinations of these identities.

Psychological and educational research has provided extensive evidence that a sense of belonging (i.e., feeling welcomed in one's field) is an important factor for student success and retention.  Regarding students' sense of belonging in computing specifically, we found some students are at higher risk for feeling less welcomed in computing. For instance, our analyses demonstrated that lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (LGBTQ) students have a lower sense of belonging in computing than their non-LGBTQ peers; and this is particularly pronounced among LGBTQ students who also identify as women.

Our findings also indicate that spending large amounts of time and effort on academic work negatively impacts women's sense of belonging in computing. In turn, lower levels of belonging is associated with a greater likelihood of considering leaving one's major. Even so, our research also showed that participating in research experiences and professional conferences are effective ways of helping students who are underrepresented in computing feel more welcome in computing.

Students who participated in research experiences early in their undergraduate career feel more supported by a mentor, which in turn helped them feel more welcomed in their field. Similarly, students who attended professional conferences (both technical and diversity focused) are also more likely to have a greater sense of belonging to computing. Our findings indicate that research experiences and conference participation are also associated with higher levels of self-confidence.

Looking specifically at the effects of various diversity-focused conferences (such as Grace Hopper Celebration and Richard Tapia Conference), the project team found that participation in these types of events have a strong positive impact on the level of mentorship support students feel and their confidence in their ability to complete their degree program. We also found that students who are engaged in undergraduate research experiences early on are more likely to intend to obtain a graduate degree (Master's or higher) than the students who did not participate in formal research activities early on. Once again, these finds were especially pronounced for students who identify as women and/or as a member of racial/ethnic groups underrepresented in computing.

Finally, we also conducted research specifically on first generation college students. Our findings showed that women who are first generation college students performed less well in computing than women who are continuing generation students; however, for first generation women, feeling as though one's department is supportive and encouraging is associated with stronger performance. Moreover, we found that first generation college women in introductory computer science courses feel more confident in their academic abilities when they interact with (versus do not interact with) faculty outside of the classroom.

Our research through this project strived to provide a comprehensive understanding of how best to support and retain students from a broad range of backgrounds in computing career tracks. CERP data has benefited, and will continue to benefit, other research projects in addition to providing valuable insights to the computing community as a whole. Beyond this award, the project team will continue to make strides toward providing evidence-based research to support equity and inclusion in the field of computing and technology.
